The slick has now grown to about 1,500 square miles, and is moving at a speed of about 42,000 gallons a day, more than double the size of the previous size. BP, which leased the rig, says it will take at least 24 to 36 hours to stop the oil, which is leaking from an uncapped well. The spill has the potential to damage beaches, barrier islands, and wetlands across the coastline. Eleven workers are still missing and presumed to have been killed in the accident. Underwater robots dived to the ocean floor yesterday in a new effort to staunch the 42,000 gallons of oil a day being pumped into the Gulf of Mexico in America's worst offshore oil rig in 40 years. – The Coast Guard says that no oil appears to be leaking from a drilling rig that exploded and sank in the Gulf of Mexico, though officials are trying to contain what spilled after the blast and prevent any threat to the coast's fragile ecosystem. The search continued for 11 workers missing after the explosion late Tuesday on the Deepwater Horizon, though family members said they had been told they probably did not survive. The fire was out, but officials initially feared as much as 336,000 gallons of crude oil a day could be rising from the sea floor nearly 5,000 feet below. The Coast Guard says that no oil appears to be leaking from a rig that sank off Louisiana on Thursday. Crews will continue to monitor the rig closely amid concerns over a possible environmental disaster. BP chief executive Tony Hayward vowed that the company would do everything in its power to contain any spills and limit the environmental impact. Click here for more.

– The scale of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico was revealed by the Coast Guard today, and it's getting worse by the day. The Coast Guard estimates that 5,000 barrels a day are leaking, five times more than the 1,000 barrels a day that were thought to be coming from the Deepwater Horizon rig when it exploded last week. The military has joined the cleanup effort, and Homeland Security has labeled the spill one of the country's "national significance," the Telegraph reports. BP shares fell 7% today after the company admitted that the amount of oil being spilled was much higher than thought.

– BP's chairman is blaming a "failed piece of equipment" for the massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. Lamar McKay told ABC's This Week that a dome that could be placed over the well is expected to be deployed in six to eight days. But he said he believes a dome that could be placed over the well is expected to be deployed in six to eight days. The spill, which has tripled in size in just days, is still expected to take at least a week to cut off, notes the Los Angeles Times. Louisiana Gov. Bobby Jindal warned that the spill threatens the very way of life of people in his state. "This is going to ruin our way of life and our way of life for years to come," he told WWLTV.

– BP is sending a giant concrete-and-steel box to the Gulf of Mexico to slow the oil spill, but it will take at least a day to build it. The 40-foot, 70-ton box, which resembles a primitive space rocket, will be connected to a drill ship and lowered to the sea floor, the BBC reports. It will be able to contain the oil better than BP's current containment effort, which involves pumping mud into the pipe. But it won't be able to do the same thing with the bigger box. "There's no guarantees," says BP chief Tony Hayward. "We'll undoubtedly encounter some issues as we go through that process." For more on the spill, click here.

– BP sent a giant box to the site of the Gulf oil spill today in what it says will be its best chance yet to contain the mess. The 100-ton box—the size of a picnic basket—was lowered over the gusher by a crane onto a barge, reports the BBC. It will be placed on the venting well of the sunken Deepwater Horizon rig later today to slow the spread of the oil. It's the first time such a device has been used so far below the surface, notes the AP, and it's designed to funnel the oil to a tanker. The US plans to burn some of the oil before placing the box over the gusher to slow the spread of it.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil spilling in the Gulf of Mexico hit a snag today when the company had to move a containment dome over the leak. The 98-ton dome was lowered over the well yesterday in an effort to collect the oil and siphon it to the surface, but it had to be moved because of ice-like crystals. BP says it will take 48 hours to assess the problem and come up with a new solution, but it could take two to three months to drill the relief well that will be used to plug the leak. Louisiana officials, meanwhile, plan to ask BP to pay for the dredging of miles of new barrier islands to protect their coast, reports Reuters.

– BP plans to place a smaller containment dome over the gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico within 72 hours, CEO Tony Hayward said today. The company is also considering a “junk shot” of golf balls and tires to try to slow the oil flow, the Telegraph reports. BP chief operating officer Doug Suttles said the junk shot is one of several ideas under consideration. The company has deployed hundreds of miles of oil booms along the Gulf Coast, but the ooze is still spreading. BP will attempt to lower a smaller containment dome over the well within 72 hours, Hayward said. The top hat dome could be in place within 72 hours, he said. The latest bid to plug the gushing well comes after previous attempts to stem the flow failed. A growing slick from the BP-leased rig is threatening an environmental disaster along US coasts.

– The first underwater video of the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico has been posted on BP's YouTube channel, after more than two weeks of silence. The video shows oil leaking from a broken pipe 5,000 feet below the surface, the Guardian reports. It's the first time BP has released footage of the spill, which is still spreading oil into the Gulf. Click here for more on the oil spill.

– BP's latest attempt to contain the oil spilling in the Gulf of Mexico failed last night, but the company says it may be able to do it permanently within a week, reports the Los Angeles Times. BP inserted a mile-long tube into the gushing well yesterday to capture most of the oil, but it failed because of mechanical trouble with the pipe. It's not clear whether it will work, but if it does, the company will siphon the oil to a ship on the surface. Two members of President Obama's Cabinet have demanded that BP chief Tony Hayward explain in detail the company's commitment to pay for damage caused by the spill, notes the Guardian.

– The first oil from the Gulf spill has entered the Loop Current, which could carry it to Florida and the East Coast, scientists say. A small portion of oil sheen has entered the current, which circulates in the Gulf, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration says. A tide of sludgy oil has begun washing into Louisiana's coastal marshes, officials said Tuesday, as BP continued to siphon some of the oil gushing from a damaged well on the gulf floor but remained days away from trying to cap the leak. Interior Secretary Ken Salazar told Senate committees Tuesday that the company would attempt a " dynamic kill" of the oil well Saturday. That procedure involves pumping thick mud into the well in hopes of blocking the oil. European scientists warn the spill could reach Florida within six days. Tar balls, sticky clumps of decayed oil, were found Monday in Key West, Fla. The Coast Guard says the tar balls found off Key West are not linked to the Gulf oil spill. A report released Wednesday says tests show the tar balls do not match the type of oil from the Deepwater Horizon spill. – The Coast Guard's Thad Allen will continue to serve as President Obama's point man on the Gulf oil spill after he retires this month, the administration said today. Allen was appointed national incident commander last month to coordinate the government's response to the spill. Homeland Security Secretary Janet Napolitano said today that he will continue to serve as national incident commander by the end of May, but will be relieved of his other duties by the end of the month. Allen said in a statement that the changes will allow him to focus solely on this critical response, and Commandant Adm. Thad Allen on the vital work of the Coast Guard." BP said it had siphoned 2,200 barrels in the 24-hour period to midnight on Thursday, down from an estimate of 5,000 barrels earlier in the day. The US government has formed a team to develop a more precise estimate of the amount of oil gushing from the well. BP will attempt to stem the oil flow next week, instead of Sunday as hoped. Two activists scaled the BP building in London today in protest. The Greenpeace campaigners hoisted a flag depicting the multinational's logo smothered in oil and emblazoned with the words "British Polluters" from a balcony above the entrance to the company's UK headquarters in St. James

– Interior Secretary Ken Salazar promised today to “keep our boot on their neck until the job gets done” in the face of BP’s failure to plug the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico. “BP Plc would be accountable, civilly and in whatever way is necessary,” Salazar said on a tour of the Gulf, where oil has been washing up on shores from Louisiana to Florida. Earlier, BP pledged to spend 500 million dollars to study the impact of the spill on marine life, the Telegraph reports. “Everyone is frustrated,” said BP chief Tony Hayward. “BP has made a commitment to doing everything we can to lessen the impact of this tragic incident on the people and environment of the Gulf Coast.”

– The Coast Guard and BP say the company's latest plan to plug the Gulf oil spill is likely to go forward tomorrow as planned. BP CEO Tony Hayward says the so-called "top kill" procedure, which involves pumping mud into the gushing well, is likely to go forward as planned after tests show it is safe, the BBC reports. The Coast Guard and BP say the "top kill" procedure has been tried on land but has failed to stop the oil spill, which has surpassed the Exxon Valdez spill as the worst in US history.

– BP's latest attempt to plug its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico failed today, the company announced. The company is shifting to a new strategy, one that involves shooting mud into the well to plug it, but it could take up to four days to know for sure. "We have not been able to stop the flow," said BP's chief operating officer. "We have made the decision to move on to the next option, which is the lower marine riser package cap, which captures oil from the well rather than plug it." It's not clear how much oil is leaking, but the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports that it's already washing up on beaches from Louisiana to Florida. Click here for more.

– The White House says the Gulf oil spill is the worst environmental disaster the US has ever faced, and it's prepared for the worst-case scenario that the spill won't be stopped until at least August, reports the BBC. BP says it will try a "top kill" operation this week, but its chief operating officer says that even if it worked, it would only halt a majority of the spill. The Obama administration says the spill could grow by 20% after BP gets started with its latest effort to contain it, beginning today or tomorrow. The president's energy adviser, Carol Browner, said the US was "prepared for the worst scenario" that the leak might not be stopped before August, notes the Times-Picayune.

– Shares in BP plunged as much as 20% today, wiping about $15 billion off the company's market value, after it failed to plug the oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico with its so-called "top kill" plan. BP said it hoped to contain the oil within 24 hours with a cap, but the Coast Guard's Thad Allen said it could be as many as 3 days before oil can be siphoned to the surface. The share price drop came as the US government repeated its warning that the "long-term solution" to the oil spill could take until August—or later—to complete. The public relations strategy for dealing with a disaster such as the Gulf of Mexico spill, now officially the worst in US history, was always going to be about damage limitation, the Guardian notes. BP chief Tony Hayward is under fire for making insensitive remarks on the oil spill. "I'd like my life back," he told the Guardian. "There's no one who wants this over more than I do."

– The live video feed of BP's latest attempt to contain the oil in the Gulf of Mexico is showing no sign of progress, reports the Wall Street Journal. The company placed a cap on the gushing well last night, but it remains unclear whether it will work, and the Coast Guard says it will be 24 to 48 hours before they know for sure. Facebook groups dedicated to boycotting BP are gaining steam, notes the BBC, with more than 350,000 members as of this writing.

– A major Swedish bank has unloaded all its shares in BP, citing the oil giant's lack of transparency over the Gulf oil spill, the BBC reports. Nordea sold off about 11 million shares, or 1.8% of its shares, across about 20 funds. "The environmental catastrophe in the Mexican Gulf is an extraordinary situation given the size of the spill, weak response from BP, criminal investigation towards the company as well as anticipated risk for other accidents," the bank said. BP shares were up 2.7% on the London Stock Exchange today.

– Looks like BP CEO Tony Hayward's days are numbered. The company has paid Google and other search engine providers to make it easier for people to access information about the Gulf oil spill by directing them to its website, the BBC reports. A spokesman said BP would pay fees so its own website would rank higher or even top in the list of advertisements that appear alongside search results for terms like "oil spill" and "volunteer." BP said it wanted to help people who were trying to access information on the BP website to find it more readily, rather than intending to draw away hits from other sites. "We know people are looking for those terms on our website and we're just trying to make it easier for them to get directly to those terms," the spokesman said.

– The US Coast Guard has given BP 48 hours to find out how it will be able to contain the oil gushing into the Gulf of Mexico. In a letter to the oil giant, Rear Adm. James Watson said that the firm's current containment plan does not go far enough, and that it is "urgently needed." David Cameron spent 30 minutes on the phone with President Obama over the weekend, the BBC reports, but it's not clear exactly what Obama said in the conversation. Obama's blunt criticism of BP over the spill has prompted accusations of "anti-British" language from some in Britain, but the president assured Cameron that his frustration over the spill is not about national identity, reports the Guardian. BP's board will meet Monday to consider withholding the latest tranche of a $7 billion annual payout to shareholders.

– President Obama will address the nation tonight from the Oval Office about the BP oil spill and the government's response, reports the BBC. "We will make sure that the oil spill is cleaned up, the oil is cleaned up, and the environment and the economy of the Gulf of Mexico is restored to its former state," he will say. "And we will make sure that BP is held accountable for all the damage this spill causes." The full text is here. Earlier today, Fitch cut BP's credit rating by six notches, making it the first of the three big agencies to do so, notes the Wall Street Journal.

– BP will set up a $20 billion compensation fund for victims of the Gulf oil spill and suspend dividend payments for the rest of the year, the company and the White House announced after four hours of talks at the White House. President Obama, who met with BP CEO Tony Hayward and other execs, said the company had agreed to set up the fund under the direction of Kenneth Feinberg, the man who oversaw post-9/11 compensation for victims of the 9/11 attacks. BP shares closed up almost 7% after the deal was announced, the Telegraph reports.

– Kevin Costner has developed a device to separate oil from water in the Gulf of Mexico, and he's signed a contract with BP to use it. “At its core, my dream, my dream, was designed to give us a fighting chance to fight back the oil that has got us in the throat,” Costner told reporters, according to the Guardian. Costner's company, Ocean Therapy Solutions, has signed a contract with BP to provide 32 of the devices, which are expected to be in the Gulf within the next 60 days. BP says the 100,000-barrel-a-day figure in an internal document released by Rep. Ed Markey is a low-ball estimate.

– Tony Hayward's days at the helm of BP are numbered, with the company today announcing that Robert Dudley will take charge of the company's Gulf cleanup operation, effective immediately. Dudley, a 30-year oil industry veteran who joined the company 18 months ago, will be the first American in the post, the Financial Times reports. The company also announced that it has deployed a containment cap to contain some of the oil, but it will be 24 hours before engineers know if it's working. The move comes as the Wall Street Journal reports that President Obama's job performance has sunk to the lowest level of his presidency, with his approval rating now at 45%, down 5 points from early last month.

– One of the best-known chefs in New Orleans is suing BP for damages on behalf of the city's seafood restaurants, reports the Times-Picayune. Chef Susan Spicer's complaint, filed Friday in federal court, says the restaurants have lost customers because of the oil spill and expect to lose more because of higher prices and lower tourism. It's not clear whether the suit will become a class-action one, notes the Wall Street Journal. Meanwhile, BP's share price continues to plunge, and the company's top bosses are due in Scotland today to reassure staff that the company has no plans to leave the North Sea.

– BP's efforts to contain the oil in the Gulf of Mexico have been slowed by the first hurricane of the season. Hurricane Alex, upgraded from tropical storm status late last night, is expected to hit Mexico and Texas later today and delay efforts for several days, reports the BBC. Waves as high as 12 feet are expected to delay the company's plans to employ a further system to capture more oil from the blown-out oil well until later in the week, while controlled burns of crude on the oil's surface, flights spraying dispersant chemicals, and booming operations were all halted yesterday. BP's corporate code of conduct says the company will not make political contributions in any country in the world. But it has donated $ 4.7 million to politcal advocacy groups and party organizations in the past seven years. For more on the oil spill, click here.

– A Taiwanese tanker designed to scoop up oil from the Gulf of Mexico is undergoing tests off Louisiana, reports the Times-Picayune. The "A Whale," as it's being called, is the first of its kind to be deployed in the Gulf, and it's designed to suck up as much oil as it can, then return it to the sea. It's been tested for two days, notes the Wall Street Journal. BP is paying for the spill cleanup, but some investors are calling for CEO Tony Hayward's head. Click here for more.

– tar balls from the Gulf oil spill have hit all five US Gulf states for the first time. The small amount of oil found on the Bolivar Peninsula, north-east of Galveston, came from BP's blown-out well off Louisiana, the BBC reports. Officials said it was unclear if it had drifted hundreds of miles from the leak site or had fallen from ships taking part in the clean-up operation. All five states on the Gulf have now been affected, notes the Houston Chronicle. BP shares have almost halved in value following the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, which began in April. BP's share price—which had more than halved since the Deepwater Horizon oil rig explosion in April—has staged an impressive recovery in recent weeks. Yet talk continues to circulate of a possible strategic investor in BP—either as a welcome provider of fresh capital to the company, or an unwelcome opportunist sniffing a bargain. So what are the options now for BP? On 16 June, the cost of buying financial protection for one year against a possible debt default by BP reached a staggering 10%.

– BP is set to install a bigger cap this weekend that could more than make up for the 25,000 barrels of oil currently being contained in the Gulf of Mexico. Thad Allen, the federal official in charge of the response, told a news conference that the well could be contained—but not plugged—by Sunday or Monday when the cap is installed on top of it, the Washington Post reports. The administration has been pressing BP to install the new cap, which could contain up to 80,000 barrels of oil a day, versus the 25,000 barrels currently being contained. The company plans to change caps on the gusher, a tricky task that could greatly improve the ability to capture the oil or perhaps even shut down the well. Robotic submarines working a mile underwater removed a leaking cap from the gushing Gulf oil well today, starting a painful trade-off that could greatly improve the ability to capture the oil or perhaps even shut down the well. The company had planned to change the cap only after first connecting the well to a new ship at the site, the Helix Producer, which can siphon up to 25,000 barrels of oil a day. But with a window of calm weather forecast for the next week or so, BP has accelerated its plans.

– Robotic submarines removed the cap that had been capturing some of the oil flowing from BP's Gulf of Mexico well yesterday, in the first step of replacing it with a more tightly fitting one. It will take up to a week for robots working a mile underwater to fit the new cap and seal, the BBC reports. Oil will flow mostly unchecked until the bigger containment system is installed, further hurting tourism and fishing in all five states along the Gulf Coast. BP also said there was no guarantee of success at such a depth. A fleet of 400 skimmers is in place to try to minimize the effects of increased oil loss. BP is in exclusive talks to sell up to $12 billion of assets to Apache Corporation, an American rival, including a big stake in Alaska's Prudhoe Bay, the largest oil field in North America, it was reported yesterday. Apache approached BP with the plan a few weeks ago. The British oil giant has been trying to sell assets as part of a huge fundraising campaign to meet the costs of its disastrous oil spill. – BP successfully installed a new containment cap on its gushing oil well in the Gulf of Mexico last night, but the operation has been delayed until at least today because of concerns about its ability to withstand pressure and make the leak worse, the Guardian reports. White House press secretary Robert Gibbs said the government did not want potentially dangerous pressure tests on the new, tighter cap to go ahead until BP answers questions about possible risks. Gibbs said he did not consider the delay to be—some giant setback—"a series of steps... that are being taken in order to ensure that what we're doing is being done out of an abundance of caution to do no harm."

– BP shares rose today after the company said it had stopped oil from flowing into the Gulf of Mexico for the first time since the Deepwater Horizon rig exploded in April. Shares were up as much as 5% in early trading in London, reports the BBC. BP is awaiting test results to see if the new cap is working, and President Obama welcomed the news as "good news." But he warned against premature celebration. "It is important we don't get ahead of ourselves," he said.

– The US Coast Guard has told BP that its containment cap may need to be removed from the site of the Gulf oil spill. Thad Allen, the federal official in charge of the cleanup, warned that there are three areas of concern, including a seep on the sea floor near the well and possible methane leaking from the seabed, the Guardian reports. BP has been told to submit a plan to remove the cap within three days. The company's shares fell nearly 5% in London after Allen's comments.

– Tony Hayward is set to leave his post as BP's CEO within 24 hours, the BBC reports. The move comes as the company prepares to announce this week that it has cleared itself of gross negligence in the Gulf oil spill disaster. BP has been waiting to announce Hayward's departure until it can quantify the financial costs of the spill, according to the BBC's business editor, who says the board has "in effect made up its mind that Mr. Hayward is going, even if the decision is not yet ratified."

– The federal government has begun evacuating ships working in the Gulf of Mexico ahead of Tropical Storm Bonnie, which could hit the region as early as tomorrow. The storm is moving in the direction of the Deepwater Horizon well, and BP has postponed drilling on a relief well for up to two weeks, the Guardian reports. BP has also hired more than a dozen national and local scientists with expertise in the Gulf, the BBC reports, but they can't talk to the media about their work until the company's restoration plan is approved by the government.

– Tony Hayward will step down as CEO of BP in October and take a job with the company's joint venture in Russia, Sky News reports. Robert Dudley will replace Hayward as managing director and head of BP's efforts to contain the Gulf oil spill, the BBC reports. BP said no final decision has been made about management changes, which reportedly include the departure of Hayward as chief executive in an effort to mend the company's image after the Gulf of Mexico oil spill. In other BP news: The cost of the Gulf oil spill has now passed the $10 billion mark, meaning the US and UK governments will have to bear some of the clean-up costs, the Guardian reports. Greenpeace has cut off fuel supplies to all 50 BP stations in London, but many have since reopened. BP's share price has fallen sharply since the spill, and the company's cash reserves are low, the Wall Street Journal reports.

– The X Prize Foundation is putting its money where its mouth is. It's offering a $1.4 million prize to the team that can come up with a better way to clean up the Gulf of Mexico oil spill, the Washington Post reports. The nonprofit organization, best known for creating the private spaceflight industry, wants to bring about "radical breakthroughs for the benefit of humanity." Research teams can register for the competition until April 2011. For more on the clean-up effort, click here.

– BP plans to pump mud and cement into the gushing Gulf well today in what could be one of the final steps toward permanently sealing it. The so-called "static kill" will be followed by a relief well that could seal the well permanently, the Wall Street Journal reports. The procedure, which is expected to take at least a day, is a repeat of what BP did with the first so-called "low kill" in mid-July, in which mud was pumped in to plug the well. Meanwhile, BP plans to offer one-off compensation to Gulf fishermen and others who have been affected by the spill in exchange for waiving their right to sue, the Guardian reports.

– BP's "static kill" procedure is working, the company announced today, and President Obama declared that "the long battle is finally close to coming to an end." The "static kill" is a process in which heavy mud was pumped in to plug the blown-out well. The White House energy adviser said the procedure had captured about 75% of the oil, burned off about 25%, evaporated or were broken down, and the rest was "rapidly degrading," the Guardian reports. "We are very pleased with that," said Obama, who has been under heavy criticism for what has been seen as a slow and weak response to the spill. TransOcean, the owner of the rig that exploded, saw its quarterly profits drop to about $700 million, from $880 million a year earlier, the Wall Street Journal reports.

– The price tag for the Deepwater Horizon oil spill has passed the $6 billion mark, BP announced today. The company has deposited $1.8 billion into a compensation fund set up by BP, and the rest will go to victims of the spill and states hit by the spill, the Wall Street Journal reports. Meanwhile, BP's relief well will reach the damaged well by the end of the week and start the final kill, according to the government's incident commander. Click here for more.

– Alabama is suing BP, Transocean, and Halliburton for “catastrophic harm” caused by the Gulf oil spill, the state’s attorney general said today. The lawsuits—one against BP and the other against Transocean, Halliburton, and other companies associated with the spill— seek economic and punitive damages, AL.com reports. The lawsuit accuses them of damaging Alabama’s coast and economy through “ negligent or wanton failure to adhere to recognized industry standards.”

– The White House is set to announce an early end to the moratorium on deepwater drilling that was imposed in the wake of the Deepwater Horizon oil spill, the Wall Street Journal reports. The move, which is expected to be announced as soon as next week, is part of President Obama's plan to overhaul offshore drilling, but it still needs to be approved by Congress. Meanwhile, the Guardian reports that BP has failed to update its Gulf oil spill emergency plan in more than three months. Lawyers say it should have been filed 15 days after a significant change in the worst-case scenario. The company was criticized by US politicians for having a response plan that appeared to have serious flaws, including a proposal highlighting the need to protect sea walruses, even though none exist in the Gulf, and listing one wildlife expert who died four years before the plan was approved.

– The White House's claim that 75% of the oil from the Deepwater Horizon spill has been captured, burned off, or broken down in the Gulf is looking less and less certain, at least two independent teams of scientists report in Science. Earlier this month, government scientists said that about 75% of the oil had been captured, burned off, or broken down. The second team of scientists, however, found that a huge plume of oil-based chemicals remains deep under the surface of the Gulf, extending more than 20 miles from the spill site, the BBC reports. The White House's claim that only 10% of the oil has been burned or skimmed is no better than the 10% BP was able to remove from the ocean by burning or skimming, said Rep. Ed Markey in a hearing yesterday. "It seems to me that BP's oil recovery effort comes in on the low effort of what was achievable 21 years ago during the Exxon Valdez disaster in Alaska," he said.

– BP's $20 billion Gulf oil-spill compensation fund opened for business yesterday, with hundreds of fishermen lining up to file claims. The Independent administrator, Kenneth Feinberg, promised generous payments, but said Gulf residents and businesses must give up their right to sue BP. He also promised to expedite the process, the Guardian reports. Meanwhile, a new type of oil-eating microbe has been found in the Gulf, the New York Times reports. Scientists discovered the fast-eating microbe while studying the underwater dispersion of millions of gallons of oil spilled into the Gulf following the April explosion of BP's Deepwater Horizon drilling rig. The microbe works without significantly depleting oxygen in the water, and the researchers say it could help dispose of oil plumes in the deep-sea. Meanwhile, Brad Pitt has said he would consider executing those responsible for the BP oil spill if he was in power. "I don't know why Obama ever trusted these BP guys! They would lie to their mothers," he told GQ.

– The blowout preventer that failed to stop the Deepwater Horizon oil spill is set to reach the surface of the Gulf of Mexico tomorrow, at which point government investigators will take possession of it. BP crews worked today to slowly raise the 300-ton blowout preventer that failed to stop oil from spewing into the Gulf of Mexico, careful not to damage or drop a key piece of evidence in the spill investigation. When the blowout preventer reaches the surface after its mile-long reach, the New Orleans Times-Picayune reports, government investigators will take possession of it. BP says oil spill cost up to $ 8 billion in the last month alone. The cost of the Gulf of Mexico oil disaster continues to mount up for BP BP says the cost of its Gulf of Mexico oil spill has risen to $ 399 million in claims to those affected by the spill. Last week, responsibilty for the claims was transferred to the Gulf Coast Claims Facility, which has so far paid out a total of 38.5 million. Plans to permanently seal the well were also progressing, BP said. Are the safety practices in oil on a par with standard practice in nuclear generation or the airline industry?

– BP’s internal report on the Gulf oil spill is out, and while the company takes some of the blame for the disaster, it also points the finger at its partners on the rig, Transocean and Halliburton. Transocean dismissed the report as “self-serving,” while Halliburton called it “riddled with omissions and inaccuracies,” the BBC reports. BP’s report also acknowledged for the first time that it misinterpreted a key pressure test of the well, according to the New Orleans Times-Picayune. Click here for more.

– The Obama administration's six-month ban on deepwater drilling in the Gulf of Mexico has not increased unemployment in the region, according to a new report from the administration. Louisiana and the oil and gas industry immediately disputed the finding, reports the Wall Street Journal. The report, released at a Senate hearing today, said the moratorium imposed after the BP oil spill likely caused a temporary loss of 8,000 to 12,000 jobs in the Gulf, including about 2,000 on deepwater rigs. Total industry spending in the region decreased by nearly $2 billion. BP's solution to the oil spill is expected to be permanently sealed by Sunday, notes Reuters.

– When BP's Macondo well ruptured in the Gulf of Mexico in 2010, killing 11 workers and sending millions of gallons of oil into the ocean, the company took full responsibility for the disaster and agreed to set up a $20 billion fund to help victims. But the agreement was short-lived: The well was never capped, and the blowout preventer that was supposed to be in place at the time failed to work, leading to the worst oil spill in US history. Now, a federal judge has ordered BP to pay a record $4.5 billion in damages to victims, reports the New York Times. The judge also ordered the oil giant to set up a fund to pay victims of other oil spills, including the 1989 Exxon Valdez disaster in Alaska. BP will pay $1.3 billion in damages alone, reports the Wall Street Journal.

The families of some of the victims feel "overwhelmed by anger" at the British government's response to the attacks, sources tell the Telegraph. Others blame Tony Blair's decision to go to war in Iraq for making London more vulnerable to suicide bombings. Sean Cassidy, whose son, Ciaran, was killed in the Russell Square bomb, said he would attend the service today with his wife, Veronica, and daughter, Lisa, because he hoped to be able to speak to Blair to express his anger.

The former aide to Dick Cheney is expected to be called as a witness in the trial, the Telegraph reports. Libby is accused of lying and obstructing the investigation into the leak of a CIA operative's identity.

Writing for the Daily Mail, Hitchens describes the war as " molten Old Testament fury shot through with visceral wit" and writes that "those on council estates are surrounded by the tattooed, with their pit bulls and serial partners, crack dens, open-all-hours pubs and the rest." Click for Seal's full column.

– Al-Jazeera is calling on the US and UK governments to provide a "good explanation" for claims in a leaked memo that George Bush considered bombing the news station's headquarters in Qatar at the height of last year's Iraqi insurgency. Al-Jazeera said it was still investigating the validity of the memo and whether Bush was serious about his alleged comments, but warned that if they were credible it would be "horrific and bad news not only for al-Jazeera but for every news organization around the world." The International Federation of Journalists claimed 16 journalists and other media staff have been killed at the hands of US forces in Iraq, adding that the deaths had not been properly investigated. Al-Jazeera's London bureau chief, Yofri Fouda, said: "We certainly hope it's not true, but if it turns out to be true it would be horrific and bad news not only for al-Jazeera but for every news organization around the world."

– A former senior US State Department official has accused Dick Cheney of crimes against humanity over the Bush administration's use of torture. Lawrence Wilkerson, who served as chief of staff to Colin Powell from 2002 to 2005, told the BBC that Cheney led the administration in arguing that the Geneva Conventions should be overturned. "It was certainly a domestic crime to advocate terror, and I would suspect that it is... an international crime as well," Wilkerson said. "I'm not saying that he's guilty, I'm saying that he's probably guilty of a war crime, but I'm not saying that he's not guilty of a crime." The Daily Beast notes that Wilkerson appears to have been referring to the systematic abuse of prisoners, not the torture itself.

– A British academic who warned against the dangers of Margaret Thatcher's policies and became an early Blairite has died at the age of 84. John Gray, author of 14 books and countless articles, died in his sleep at his home in southwest England, the Telegraph reports. He had been in ill health for some time. His death was announced by the University of Exeter, where he was a professor of social policy. He was the author of several books on Britain's left, including The End of the World: Why Britain Is Screwed, and The End of the World Is Screwed: Why the Left Is Screwed. He was also the author of The End of the World Is Screwed: Why the Left Is Screwed and The End of the World Is Screwed: Why the Left Is Screwed.

– In the wake of the George W. Bush speech in which he admitted "much of the intelligence used as the basis for invading Iraq had been wrong," the Guardian takes a look at the man who made the decision to go to war—and the man who still thinks it was the right thing to do. "One older man began telling me that he did not blame Tony Blair or even George Bush for the way things had turned out, because they were mere dupes of a more powerful force," writes Martin Wroe. "The calamity of 9/11 was not all it seemed: the authors of that event were not the 19 hijackers, but more shadowy players, unknown even to Bush." Read the full column here.

– Celebrities are increasingly turning down the chance to perform for US troops serving in Iraq, the Telegraph reports. Christian hip-hop groups, country singers, and two cheerleaders for the Dallas Cowboys are among the acts that have been offered the chance to perform for the troops. The military’s United Services Organization has been putting on shows for the troops since the second world war, but is struggling to get celebrities to sign up for even a short tour of duty.

– The son of Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi has promised reforms in the wake of the violent crackdown on protesters that has left more than 200 dead, the BBC reports. “There will be reforms,” Saif al-Islam Gadhafi said in a televised address. “We will build a new Libya, a free Libya, with justice, equality, and inclusiveness.” He blamed “ saboteurs” for the unrest and promised that those responsible would be “met with the full force of the state,” CNN reports. Saif al-Islam Gadhafi is the first son to address the nation since his father seized power 42 years ago.

– Mikhail Gorbachev has a message for Moammar Gadhafi: "Tomorrow, we can speak rationally, we can spare the blood, we can stand all together for the sake of Libya," the former Soviet leader told CNN. "Now is the time to stop this unacceptable bloodshed. We are working urgently with friends and partners around the world to convey this message to the Libyan government." Gadhafi's son, meanwhile, warned of a civil war if protests continue. The US is keeping a close watch on the situation, a senior Obama administration official tells CNN.

– As Moammar Gadhafi’s forces continue to pound Zawiya, the Libyan leader has blamed Osama bin Laden’s al-Qaeda for the violence, CNN reports. “Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (al-Qaeda’s North African wing) congratulates the Libyan people on their rejection of bin Laden and his ideology,” the group said in a statement posted on jihadist websites. Doctors at a field hospital in Zawiya say 17 people were killed and another 150 wounded when government forces attacked the city. They predicted the death toll would rise by morning. Six pro-regime soldiers who were captured said they had been told that the city was being run by Arab militants and it was their job to liberate it. Meanwhile, Mike Huckabee called the situation in Libya a “virtual genocide,” but said he was “still hopeful” that Gadhafi’s army would take him out.

– Moammar Gadhafi is blaming al-Qaeda for the violence against protesters in Libya, he tells ABC and the BBC in an interview picked up by CNN. "They love me, all my people with me," he says of Libya's people. "My people will die for me." Gadhafi also denied using force against his people, saying, "No demonstration at all in the streets." He blamed al-Qaeda for the violence against protesters in Benghazi, saying, "They are the ones who are killing the Libyans." Gadhafi's statements come as his security forces continue their assault on protesters in Tripoli.

– The International Criminal Court has launched an investigation into Moammar Gadhafi, his sons, and members of his inner circle for war crimes in Libya, reports the Hindustan Times. The move comes as the Arab League rejected any foreign intervention in the country. President Obama, meanwhile, said the US is considering a “full range of options” in response to the crisis, including a no-fly zone, CNN reports. Gadhafi’s government has accepted a proposal from Hugo Chavez to send an international commission to negotiate a solution, according to a spokesman for the Venezuelan president.

– The US is sending four more C-130 cargo planes to evacuate Egyptians from Libya, CNN reports. The first plane landed in Cairo today with 82 passengers on board, and two more were on their way. The flights will leave Tunisia and arrive in Cairo tomorrow, according to a US official. Meanwhile, opposition forces claimed a major victory today in Libya, managing to block an onslaught by Moammar Gadhafi's troops and maintain control of the key city of Misrata. Using machine guns, sticks, and anything else they could find, crowds protected the courthouse, serving as an operations center by the opposition in Misrata, and successfully repelled Gadhafi militias armed with tanks and heavy artillery. A doctor at Central Misrata Hospital said 42 people were killed—17 from the opposition and 25 from the pro-Gadhafi forces—and that 85 people were wounded in the fighting, which continued on the city's outskirts.

– The UN Security Council is working on a draft resolution that would authorize a no-fly zone over Libya, reports CNN. Britain and France are working on a draft resolution that would authorize a no-fly zone over Libya to prevent airstrikes against civilians in the North African country where rebels are seeking to oust long-time leader Moammar Gadhafi. The United States, however, has made clear to London and Paris that the administration of President Obama is in the throes of a policy review and is not ready—to go full steam ahead on a no-fly zone at the moment. Meanwhile, fighting continues to rage between rebels and Gadhafi's forces in key cities.

– New York Times journalists are still missing in Libya, but Moammar Gadhafi's government has promised to release them, reports the Times. Gadhafi's son, Saif al-Islam, gave an interview to ABC last night in which he said New York Times photographer Lynsey Addario would be released. The government has also promised to release three other Times journalists who were captured by Gadhafi's forces earlier this week, says the paper. The news comes as the UN Security Council voted to impose a no-fly zone over Libya, but a senior administration official tells CNN that military action won't necessarily last until Gadhafi steps down. "Right now, we're focused on stopping the violence," he says.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s forces continued their assault on Misrata today, firing tank and artillery in an attempt to retake the last major rebel stronghold in the western part of the country. But rebels say they’ve stopped the ground attack, seized some tanks from Gadhafi’s forces, and are in control of the city, according to the New York Times. “The shelling on the city stopped and the rebels have captured some tanks,” one resident tells Reuters. But Gadhafi’s forces still control much of the east of the country, including the oil port of Ras Lanuf and the city of Jedaim, according to CNN.

– Coalition forces continue to pound Moammar Gadhafi's forces in Libya, but the US military says it has no plans to hand over control to the international community. "We are not going after Gadhafi," a US admiral tells CNN. "We are going after his air defenses, his ground forces, his command and control systems. We're not going after his palaces. We're not going after his inner circle. We're going after his command and control." Meanwhile, four New York Times journalists who were captured by Gadhafi's forces last week have been released and are in Tunisia, CNN reports.

– Coalition forces are close to handing over control of the no-fly zone over Libya to NATO, the top commander of US Africa Command told CNN today. "What we have decided today is that NATO will enforce the no-fly zone," Gen. Carter Ham said. "We have achieved already a large degree of success," including the arms embargo and the halting of Moammar Gadhafi's forces near Benghazi. NATO's secretary-general, Anders Fogh Rasmussen, said the decision to transition control of the no-fly zone to NATO was "not an easy one," the AP reports. But he said the alliance had made "good progress on the no-fly zone front."

– A Libyan woman who stormed into a hotel to tell foreign reporters that she had been raped by Moammar Gadhafi's troops has been released, and her case is being investigated, a government spokesman tells CNN. Among those accused by the woman, Eman al-Obeidy is the son of a high-ranking official, he says. Among those accused by Obeidy is the son of a high-ranking official, he adds. The woman is at home with her family, he says. She "entered a place she wasn't supposed to enter," the spokesman says, adding that the matter is a criminal case against four individuals who have an attorney. The general attorney is looking into the case. Obeidy's family says they were offered money to convince her to change her story.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s forces launched a major assault on the oil port of Ras Lanuf today, in what appeared to be an attempt to retake control of the city from anti-Gadhafi rebels. Rebels were forced to retreat after being barraged with rockets and artillery from Gadhafi’s forces, a rebel source tells CNN. The loss of Ras Lanuf is a major setback for the rebels, who have also lost Misrata and Bin Jawad to Gadhafi’s forces. In other developments: Gadhafi’s foreign minister has defected, becoming the first high-ranking Libyan official to do so, CNN reports. British Prime Minister David Cameron said he had spoken with Gadhafi about the possibility of arming the rebels. President Obama has signed a secret order authorizing covert US government support for rebel forces seeking to oust Gadhafi, government officials told Reuters today.

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi launched a fierce attack on the rebel-held city of Misrata today, in what an opposition officer tells CNN was a “ massacre.” The city has been cut off from the rest of Libya by the fighting, and hundreds of people are believed to have been killed in the attack. The UN Security Council will hold an emergency meeting tomorrow to discuss the violence, which has killed more than 200 people in Misrata in the past week, the AP reports. In other developments: Turkey is trying to broker a ceasefire, but Gadhafi’s government says it will not negotiate until it has control of the capital, Tripoli, and the rest of the country. British diplomats are in Libya meeting with opposition leaders, but no decision has been made on whether to arm the rebels, CNN reports.

– The head of Libya's rebel army has slammed NATO for its slow response to attacks on civilians by Moammar Gadhafi's forces, saying the alliance was "letting the people of Misrata die every day," CNN reports. "I am extremely sorry to say this, but NATO truly disappointed us," said Gen. Abdul Fatah Younis. "If NATO wanted to free Misrata, they could have done that a few days ago." Gadhafi's forces have been using human shields and hiding military equipment in populated areas, making it difficult for NATO to order air strikes to protect civilians, the rebel leader said. "I am extremely sorry to say this, but NATO truly disappointed us."

– Moammar Gadhafi has agreed to the African Union’s peace plan for Libya, South African President Jacob Zuma told reporters today, after meeting with the Libyan leader for several hours. “He has accepted the roadmap,” Zuma said, according to the AP. But the rebels quickly rejected the plan, saying it didn’t include Gadhafi’s departure, CNN reports. Western leaders, meanwhile, reacted cautiously, saying they were waiting for more details.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s forces continued their assault on Misrata today, firing antiaircraft fire and shelling residential areas, according to Libyan state television. Human Rights Watch accused Gadhafi’s forces of using cluster munitions, which have been banned by most nations, in the attack, CNN reports. But Gadhafi’s government denies the charge, and says the cluster munitions were used in a training exercise. Meanwhile, delegates from Arab and African nations and NATO met in Qatar yesterday, promising more humanitarian aid and money channeled through a temporary trust fund of sorts. Members of what is called the Libya Contact Group agreed that a temporary financial mechanism could provide a way to get money to the Libyan opposition. German Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle said participants in the Qatari capital, Doha, were discussing the possibility of using frozen Libyan assets for the fund. – The bodies of American photographer Chris Hondros and British photojournalist Tim Hetherington, killed in the Libyan city of Misrata yesterday, arrived in the US last night, CNN reports. The pair were working on the war documentary Restrepo when they were hit by mortar fire. "To me, the most important thing is just figuring out the way to cover it," said Hondros' friend. "To me, the most important thing is just figuring out the way to protect it." The bodies of Hetherington and Hondros will be flown back to the US later today. Meanwhile, fighting continued in Misrata, with rebels claiming to have taken control of a main road in the city.

Tobruk is a rebel stronghold one hour west of the Egyptian border and is the site of a key oil exporting facility where the rebels shipped out their first consignment of oil earlier this month. Benfayed said the gunmen opened fire on a team of nine rebel military guards manning the pumping station. The rebels were guarding the station when they were attacked, and only one guard survived.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s troops are engaging in sexual violence and some have been given Viagra, UN diplomats tell Reuters. US Ambassador Susan Rice raised the issue during a closed-door Security Council meeting yesterday, but no one responded. Meanwhile, CNN reports that Gadhafi has vowed to sink any ship that approaches Misrata’s harbor, which has been a vital source of food and medical aid for the besieged city. NATO, meanwhile, says it intercepted Libyan government forces laying mines in Misrata’s harbor, which has been a lifeline for humanitarian aid in the months-long conflict between troops loyal to Gadhafi and rebels demanding an end to the bombardment of the besieged city.

– Moammar Gadhafi’s youngest son and three of his grandchildren were killed in a NATO airstrike, but the Libyan government says the longtime strongman and his wife survived, CNN reports. Gadhafi and his wife were in their son’s house when it was targeted, but they are in good health, government spokesman Mussa Ibrahim said. But the son, Saif al-Arab Gadhafi, and three of his children were killed, Ibrahim said. The Libyan government vowed to retaliate with death to “ invaders” in the nation, and empty Western embassies were vandalized on Sunday, US and Italian officials said. Meanwhile, the chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court said today he would soon ask for up to five arrest warrants against Gadhafi for crimes against humanity, Reuters reports.

– The chief prosecutor for the International Criminal Court plans to issue arrest warrants for Moammar Gadhafi and two other Libyan leaders for crimes against humanity, reports CNN. Luis Moreno-Ocampo says he has "reasonable grounds to believe that crimes against humanity have been committed and continue to be committed" in Libya. Among other things, he accuses Gadhafi's government of deporting or transferring citizens without their consent, and of raping women. He plans to seek warrants for the arrests of Gadhafi, Libyan Foreign Minister Moussa Koussa, and Gadhafi's son Saif al-Islam. The news comes as Hillary Clinton meets with allies in Rome to discuss the Libya crisis. “As long as Gadhafi continues to attack his citizens, we will continue to strike his forces,” she said.

– Libyan strongman Moammar Gadhafi’s wife and daughter have fled the country, crossing the border into Tunisia, a Tunisian security source tells CNN. It’s unclear whether they were on a diplomatic mission or seeking safe haven, but Arabic television stations quoted Tunisian officials as denying that the family members were in the country, saying that Safia Gadhafi and daughter Aisha were on a UN sanctions list and would therefore not be allowed in. Meanwhile, the chief prosecutor of the International Criminal Court told CNN that Libyan security forces are using sexual enhancement drugs as a machete and gang-raping women they stop at checkpoints. “There are rapes,” says ICC chief prosecutor Luis Moreno-Ocampo. “The issue is who organized them.”

– Moammar Gadhafi’s forces launched their biggest attack yet against a rebel stronghold in western Libya yesterday, one of the Libyan leader’s former generals tells CNN. The attack on Zintan began at dawn and continued through today, when rebels sounded an alarm over NATO bombings of three ports they said would trigger a crisis by limiting the movement of supply ships carrying critical supplies in and out of the war-torn nation. NATO jets destroyed eight Libyan warships in the ports of Tripoli, Al-Khums, and Sirte after concluding that Gadhafi had started using naval assets to lay mines and hamper international humanitarian aid, said a NATO military spokesman. Libyan officials said, however, that the airstrikes violated the United Nations resolution mandating the protection of civilians. The EU is considering blacklisting Libyan ports to prevent exports of oil and imports of fuel, a Western diplomatic source tells Reuters. The source said European Union experts have reached an agreement over putting the Libyan ports of Tripoli, Zuara, Zawiyah, Al-Khoms, Ras Lanuf, and Brega on the sanctions list and proposals could be submitted to the EU sanctions committee next week.

– Fresh explosions were heard near Tripoli this morning, hours after South African President Jacob Zuma met with Moammar Gadhafi and signaled he was ready to accept an African Union plan for a cease-fire. A Libyan government official said the first strike hit Abu Sita, a former military turned construction site about 6 miles from the city center. A second blast was heard about 5 minutes later, CNN reports. Gadhafi's forces have blockaded roads in and out of the region, leaving residents with no access to food or water. Still people here are adamant about defending their land—young people in military training camps use antique guns to fight off Gadhafi's forces. Meanwhile, another blow to the Gadhafi regime: Libya's oil minister confirmed today that he's defected and said he's considering signing up with the opposition movement. Shukri Ghanem told CNN in Rome that he left Libya because the suffering of the people became too unbearable. "This war is getting even worse every day and there is no end to it and we would like NATO to stop its bombardment."

At least one person is thought to have died in their custody, according to a Human Rights Watch report picked up by CNN. Dozens of civilians are being held without trial or due process, the report says. Meanwhile, Russian President Dmitry Medvedev has sent an envoy to Libya to meet with rebels trying to bring about an end to Gadhafi's 42-year rule, CNN reports. "My task is to meet with rebel leaders," Medvedev said. "However, I do not rule out that I may have to go to Tripoli, too, if I get the corresponding order from the president." Gadhafi, meanwhile, said in a live audio broadcast on state television that "we will not surrender," even as NATO airstrikes bombarded his compound in Tripoli. "I am now speaking as planes and bombs fall around me," he said. "But my soul is in God's hand. We will not think about death or life."

– Forces loyal to Moammar Gadhafi launched a new attack on the rebel-held city of Misrata yesterday, with anti-government forces reporting intense shelling from three sides of the city. Thousands of government troops attacked around 6am and around 11pm, with 13 rebels reported dead by evening. Mohamed Mokhtar, a rebel fighter wounded in yesterday's fighting, accused government troops of infiltrating rebel lines in cars bearing rebel flags. A CNN source says NATO believes the UN resolution on Libya justifies killing Gadhafi because, as head of the military, he is part of the control and command structure and therefore a legitimate target. Western and Arab nations meet in Abu Dhabi today to focus on what one US official called the "end-game" for Libya's Muammar Gadhafi. NATO air strikes resumed in Tripoli on Wednesday night after a lull that followed the heaviest day of bombings since March.

– A NATO airstrike on a residential area of Tripoli this morning killed at least nine people, including three children, according to the Libyan government. “This is cold-blooded murder,” said a government spokesman, according to CNN. NATO is investigating the incident. The strike occurred near the port city of Misrata, where rebels have been fighting Gadhafi's forces for more than a week.

– As the US steps up its involvement in Libya, Moammar Gadhafi is losing control of the western part of the country, US and NATO officials tell the Wall Street Journal. Gadhafi's forces have been retaking territory from rebels in the western town of Jedaim, and he has also lost control of the oil port of Ras Lanuf. "He is losing control of his forces in the western part of the country," a NATO official says. "He has lost control of most of his oil facilities in the western part of the country." In other developments: A NATO airstrike hit a bakery and restaurant in the rebel-held city of al-Brega today, killing 15 civilians, a Libyan government official tells CNN, though NATO says there is no sign that it killed civilians in its strikes. The defecting members of Libya's national soccer team were greeted by cheering crowds and celebratory gunfire when they arrived in the rebel stronghold of Zintan.

– France is in talks with Libyan rebels about supplying them with weapons and ammunition, a Libyan opposition military spokesman in Misrata said late yesterday. The French government has not confirmed the claim, which follows an acknowledgement earlier this week that its military has previously dropped light weaponry to rebels elsewhere. Ibrahim Baitalmal, the spokesman for Misrata's Military Council, said that if the French agreed to help in Misrata, anti-Gadhafi forces there would receive much needed supplies to fight against Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi's forces. Meanwhile, CNN reports that women from around Gadhafi's Tripoli stronghold are traveling south to a training facility in Bani Walid to practice with weapons, a common sight in a country where young girls receive military training in schools.

– UN envoy Abdul Elah al-Khatib will head to Tripoli today to meet with Moammar Gadhafi and rebel leaders in an attempt to end the conflict, CNN reports. The UN special envoy is looking for a “political process” that will end the conflict, but he says a firm initiative hasn’t yet been worked out. Meanwhile, Gadhafi’s son Saif al-Islam says his father is willing to step down if NATO pulls out of Libya. “If NATO pulls out, Moammar Gadhafi will step down,” Saif al-Islam told Qatar’s al-Jazeera TV, according to the Telegraph. “If NATO pulls out, I will step down, too.” Meanwhile, Turkey has begun delivering fuel to rebel-held eastern Libya as part of a $10 million deal, Reuters reports.

– The British government's decision to kick Moammar Gadhafi's diplomats out of London is bad news for Libya's rebels and good news for the North African nation's future, writes Rania El Gamal and Stephen Addison at CNN. The rebels now have a "power vacuum" in their army, they say, thanks to the death of their military chief, Gen. Abdul Fattah Younis, along with two senior officers. The news comes as rebels prepare for a new offensive against Gadhafi's troops, notes Reuters. "We are reinforcing the position around Nalut and we will attack Ghezaia tomorrow or the next day for sure," says a rebel spokesman. "We plan to take it."

– The US State Department is handing over the Libyan embassy in Washington to the rebels, CNN reports. The move comes after a formal request from the Transitional National Council, which is now running the country. The US has frozen the embassy's 13 million-dollar bank account as part of its support for the rebels, who are fighting to oust Moammar Gadhafi. The move will allow the rebels to reopen the embassy, accredit diplomats, and gain control of the bank account. Meanwhile, the front lines between Gadhafi's forces and the rebels continue to move forward.

– Tunisian authorities have seized five truckloads of gasoline being smuggled across the border into Libya, in a bid to curb an illegal trade that is helping to keep Moammar Gadhafi in power, reports Reuters. The trucks were seized in the town of Msaken, near the Libyan border, and authorities say the fuel would have helped keep Gadhafi's forces in control of the country's east. The crackdown comes as the International Committee of the Red Cross warns that hospitals, health care workers, and ambulances are increasingly being targeted in conflicts from Libya to Somalia, depriving millions of sick and wounded of treatment. The ICRC has documented security incidents in 16 countries that disrupted delivery of health care, many of them deliberate attacks violating international humanitarian law.

Heavy gunfire was heard in al-Zawiya, located about 33 miles west of Tripoli, where rebels had arrived. CNN reporter Craig Johnston sensed something was about to change about an hour and a half into his trip from the Tunisian border to Tripoli on Saturday, when he was caught in the gunfire outside al-Zawiya.
